ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: What is the primary reason for the author to suggest that the Army has to shrink?
ENGLISH.OPT1: The reduced Soviet threat in Europe.
ENGLISH.OPT2: The lack of strategy on the part of the Defense Secretary.
ENGLISH.OPT3: To transform themselves into lightly equipped troops.
ENGLISH.OPT4: To avoid conflicts between the Marine Corps and the Army.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 1 to 3: The passage given below is followed by a set of three questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

During the years of the Reagan military build-up, Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger let each service buy every weapon on its wish list, unhindered by any overall strategic concept. Richard Cheney, the present Secretary, seems to be conducting the build-down with the same disdain for forethought. For lack of an overall strategy, the services are fighting one another for roles and dollars.

As the Soviet threat diminishes, a sniping war has broken out between the Army and the Marine Corps. If the need to fight a war in Europe diminishes, the Army will either have to shrink considerably or find new missions. Its leadership has accepted the need to shrink somewhat, and seeks to prevent further cuts by reorganizing the remaining troops into light divisions that can be quickly airlifted to trouble spots in the third world.

That"s a reasonable plan but, if pushed too far, it would conflict with the mission of the Marine Corps, which specializes in amphibious landings on unfriendly shores. Unlike the Army, the Corps has its own transport, the Navy, and its own air force.

As Soviet forces in Europe are substantially reduced, it seems inevitable that there will be a lesser role for the Army, which is specialized for fighting a heavily mechanized war with pre-positioned equipment. For the foreseeable future, the Army needs to maintain that capability, even as its overall size is reduced. For the longer term, it seems prudent to sustain at least the shell of an organization that can fight major land wars.

A role for the Army in third world conflicts is complicated. It must depend on foreign bases, which risks political problems, or on lightly equipped troops that can be transported by air. But the limited weight of equipment that can be transported this way may not be enough.

During the conflict in the Persian Gulf, the major role was played by the Navy, with very little opportunity for Army or Air Force involvement. For these kinds of situations, a strong Navy and Marine Corps seem to be the best solution.

The Army-Marine Corps tussle is a proper debate, and there will be many others like it as the services compete for slices of a shrinking pie. But unless Mr. Cheney provides a strategic road map for future defense needs, these disputes will be settled in the worst way possible, by log-rolling among the services and parochial politicking in Congress.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: Which of the following suggestions, if implemented, would most likely result in heightened competition between the Army and the Marine Corps?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Maintain the ability to fight a highly mechanized war.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Reorganize the army into effectively armed divisions that can be easily transported to areas of conflict.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Maintain foreign bases in third world countries.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Develop air lifting capabilities which would help the Army transport heavy equipment to troubled areas.

ENGLISH.OPT3: The conflict between Army and Marine Corps.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: The author provides the example of “value-added” model of teacher evaluations in the penultimate paragraph primarily to
ENGLISH.OPT1: emphasize that the statistical models for evaluation are usually controversial.
ENGLISH.OPT2: highlight the inadequacies of statistical models which are based on poor metrics.
ENGLISH.OPT3: illustrate the near impossibility of designing an algorithm for monitoring harder-to-quantify qualities.
ENGLISH.OPT4: indicate that statistical models cannot be used for evaluating employees’ performance.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 4 to 6: The passage given below is followed by a set of three questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

A century ago, a man named Frederick Winslow Taylor changed the way workers work. In his book The Principles of Scientific Management, Taylor made the case that companies needed to be pragmatic and methodical in their efforts to boost productivity. By observing employees’ performance and whittling down the time and effort involved in doing each task, he argued, management could ensure that their workers … did all sorts of “crude and elementary” work as efficiently as possible. “Soldiering” – a common term in the day for the manual laborer’s loafing – would no longer be possible under the rigors of the new system, Taylor wrote.

The principles of data-driven planning first laid out by Taylor … have transformed the modern workplace ... And as the metrics have become more precise in their detail, their focus has shifted beyond the tasks themselves and onto the workers doing those tasks, evaluating a broad range of their qualities and tying corporate carrots and sticks … to those ratings.

In her illuminating new book, Weapons of Math Destruction, the data scientist Cathy O’Neil describes how companies, schools, and governments evaluate consumers, workers, and students based on ever more abundant data about their lives. She makes a convincing case that this reliance on algorithms has gone too far: Algorithms often fail to capture unquantifiable concepts such as workers’ motivation and care, and discriminate against the poor and others who can’t so easily game the metrics.

Basing decisions on impartial algorithms rather than subjective human appraisals would appear to prevent the incursion of favoritism, nepotism, and other biases. But as O’Neil thoughtfully observes, statistical models that measure performance have biases that arise from those of their creators. As a result, algorithms are often unfair and sometimes harmful. “Models are opinions embedded in mathematics,” she writes.

One example O’Neil raises is the “value-added” model of teacher evaluations, used controversially in New York City schools and elsewhere, which decide whether teachers get to keep their jobs based in large part on what she calls a straightforward but poor and easily fudged proxy for their overall ability: the test scores of their students. According to data from New York City, she notes … that “the evaluation data is practically random.” Meanwhile, harder-to-quantify qualities such as how well teachers engage their students or manage the classrooms go largely ignored. …

How might these flaws be addressed? O’Neil’s argument boils down to a belief that some of these algorithms aren’t good or equitable enough – yet. Ultimately, she writes, they need to be refined with sounder statistical methods or tweaked to ensure fairness and protect people from disadvantaged backgrounds.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: According to Cathy O’Neil, which of the following is a shortcoming of statistical models that measure performance?
ENGLISH.OPT1: The creators of statistical models rig these models so that they are beneficial to the people they like.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Most of the statistical models ignore the data related to the metrics that are critical for evaluating performance.
ENGLISH.OPT3: It is difficult to design statistical models which can link the multitude of metrics which go into performance evaluation.
ENGLISH.OPT4: The biases of the creators of the statistical models end up in the algorithms which makes the algorithms unfair.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: Which of the following approaches would Frederick Winslow Taylor have most likely discussed in his book The Principles of Scientific Management?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Using data-dependent statistical models for evaluating the performance of the workers.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Using a data-driven approach for determining the optimum time required to complete tasks which require less skill.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Using a data-driven approach for incentivizing workers to improve their efficiency.
ENGLISH.OPT4: Using a data-dependent approach for discriminating between the slackers and exceptional performers.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: According to the passage, why was the Renaissance slow to arrive in England?
ENGLISH.OPT1: There was a dearth of architects, craftsmen and pattern-books.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Queen Elizabeth had a worrisome association with Catholic Europe and the relative isolation of England from the European cultural mainstream impeded the free interchange of suggestions.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Rules of architecture in Elizabeth’s reign were archaic and stringent and they cramped the genius of the architect masters.
ENGLISH.OPT4: The ‘fitness for purpose’ ethos of medieval architecture continued to reign supreme in the “building boom” of the 16th century.
ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 7 to 12: The passage given below is followed by a set of six questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

Architecture is about evolution, not revolution. It used to be thought that once the Romans pulled out of Britain in the fifth century, their elegant villas and carefully-planned towns ... simply fell into decay as British culture was plunged into the Dark Ages. It took the Norman Conquest of 1066 and the Gothic cathedral-builders of the Middle Ages to bring back the light and revive the British culture.

However, the truth is not as simple as that. Romano-British culture including architecture survived long after the Roman withdrawal. And although the Anglo-Saxons had a sophisticated building style of their own, little survives to bear witness to their achievements as the vast majority of Anglo-Saxon buildings were made of wood.

The period between the Norman landing at Pevensey in 1066 and the day in 1485 when Richard III lost his horse and his head at Bosworth, ushering in the Tudors and the Early Modern period, marks a rare flowering of British building. ... The underlying ethos of medieval architecture was "fitness for purpose". The great cathedrals were fiercely functional buildings. Castles served their purpose and their battlements were for use rather than ornament. The rambling manor houses of the later Middle Ages, however, were primarily homes, their owners achieving respect by their hospitality and good lordship rather than the grandeur of their buildings. However, the houses of the poor were dark, primitive structures of one or two rooms, usually with crude timber frames, low walls and thatched roofs.

The buildings of the 16th century were also governed by fitness for purpose but the purpose was very different. In domestic architecture, buildings were used to display status and wealth. A greater sense of security led to more outward-looking buildings, as opposed to the medieval arrangement where the need for defence created houses that faced inward onto a courtyard or series of courtyards. This allowed for much more in the way of exterior ornament. The rooms themselves tended to be bigger and lighter ... There was also a general move towards balanced and symmetrical exteriors with central entrances. In addition there was progress towards more stable and sophisticated houses for those lower down the social scale. Stone, and later brick, began to replace timber as the standard building material for the homes of farmers and artisans.

In spite of this building boom, the Renaissance was generally slow to arrive in England, largely because Elizabeth"s troublesome relations with Catholic Europe made the free exchange of ideas difficult. Craftsmen and pattern-books did come over from the Protestant Low Countries, but our relative isolation from the European cultural mainstream led to a national style which was a bizarre though attractive mixture of Gothic and classical styles.

But during the 1640s and 50s, the Civil War sent many people to the Continent either to escape the fighting or, when the war was lost, to follow Charles II into exile. There they came into contact with French, Dutch and Italian architecture and, with Charles"s restoration in 1660, there was a flurry of building activity as royalists reclaimed their property and built themselves houses reflecting the latest European trends.

As the century wore on, this resolved itself into a passion for the Baroque grandeur which Louis XIV had turned into an instrument of statecraft at Versailles. Formal, geometrical and symmetrical planning meant that a great lord could sit in his dining chamber, at the physical as well as the metaphorical centre of his world, with suites of rooms radiating out in straight lines to either side. His gardens would reflect those lines in long, straight walks and avenues.

The British Baroque was a reassertion of authority, an expression of absolutist ideology by men who remembered a world turned upside down during the Civil War. The style is heavy and rich, sometimes overblown and melodramatic.

By the end of the 18th century, the idea of a single national style of architecture had had its day. ... The Cult of Styles had arrived.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: The second para of the passage serves which of the following purposes?
ENGLISH.OPT1: It presents an alternative hypothesis and provides arguments that support it.
ENGLISH.OPT2: It challenges the validity of a theory by exposing the inconsistencies and contradictions in it.
ENGLISH.OPT3: It explains an implicit idea by reiterating a point.
ENGLISH.OPT4: It arrests the reader's attention and clears a misconception by providing an alternative explanation.

ENGLISH.OPT1: In the 16th century, a greater sense of security led to more outward-looking buildings heightening the exterior embellishment on display.

Architecture is about evolution, not revolution. It used to be thought that once the Romans pulled out of Britain in the fifth century, their elegant villas and carefully-planned towns ... simply fell into decay as British culture was plunged into the Dark Ages. However, the truth is not as simple as that. Romano-British culture including architecture survived long after the Roman withdrawal. And although the Anglo-Saxons had a sophisticated building style of their own, little survives to bear witness to their achievements as the vast majority of Anglo-Saxon buildings were made of wood.

The period between the Norman landing at Pevensey in 1066 and the day in 1485 when Richard III lost his horse and his head at Bosworth, ushering in the Tudors and the Early Modern period, marks a rare flowering of British building. ... The underlying ethos of medieval architecture was "fitness for purpose". The great cathedrals were fiercely functional buildings. Castles served their purpose and their battlements were for use rather than ornament. The rambling manor houses of the later Middle Ages, however, were primarily homes, their owners achieving respect by their hospitality and good lordship rather than the grandeur of their buildings. However, the houses of the poor were dark, primitive structures of one or two rooms, usually with crude timber frames, low walls and thatched roofs.

A greater sense of security led to more outward-looking buildings, as opposed to the medieval arrangement where the need for defence created houses that faced inward onto a courtyard or series of courtyards. DIRECTIONS for questions 13 to 18: The passage given below is followed by a set of six questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

Music is a form of emotional communication, with which the performer conveys an emotional state to the listener. This “language” is remarkably powerful – it can evoke strong emotions. And it is universal – the emotional content of music can be understood by anyone, regardless of cultural background.

Are the emotions evoked by a piece of music similar to, and can they influence, other emotional experiences? ... A new study provides both behavioural and physiological evidence that the emotions evoked by music can be transferred to the sense of vision, and can influence how the emotions in facial expressions are perceived.

For their study, Nidhya Logeswaran and Joydeep Bhattacharya, of Goldsmiths College in London, performed two separate experiments. In the first, 30 participants were presented with a series of happy or sad musical excerpts, each lasting 15 seconds. After each piece of music, the participants were shown a photograph of a face, expressing either a happy, sad, or neutral expression. The photographs were flashed on a screen for 1 second, after which the participants were asked to rate the emotion on a 7-point scale, where 1 denotes extremely sad and 7 extremely happy.

Thus, the visual emotional stimuli – the photos of faces – were “primed” by an emotional state conveyed by a piece of music. All the participants correctly identified the emotions expressed by the faces in the photographs presented to them. However, happy faces primed by a happy piece of music were rated as happier than when primed by sad music. Conversely, sad faces primed by a piece of sad music were rated as sadder than those primed with a happy piece of music. Finally, neutral faces were rated higher when primed by a happy piece of music and lower when primed by a sad piece.

The size of the priming effect for neutral faces was found to be almost twice that of the effect for happy and sad faces. Neutral faces contain less information than those expressing one emotion or the other, and hence are ambiguous. The brain integrates information from different senses to construct representations of the external and internal worlds; thus, in the absence of relevant visual information, it may therefore become more reliant on information from other senses when generating these representations.

The second experiment involved 15 different participants. Logeswaran and Bhattacharya used electroencephalogram (EEG) to record event-related potentials – the electrical activity in the brain associated with perception of the auditory and visual stimuli presented. A number of earlier EEG studies have shown that our emotional responses to music are associated with distinct patterns of brain activation – a happy piece of music causes an increase in activity recorded from electrodes lying over the left frontal and temporal lobes, while pieces of music which evoke negative emotions are associated with increased activity in the right frontal and temporal lobe. A similar lateralized effect has also been observed for emotionally significant visual stimuli.

The researchers compared pairs of conditions in which photographs of the same facial emotion were primed differently. In both conditions, a signal associated with the later stages of face processing, called the face-specific N170 component, was measured from electrodes overlying the occipital and parietal lobes, initially from frontal and central electrodes, followed by more activity in the electrodes located toward the back of the skull. However, a difference was observed between those in conditions in which neutral faces were primed by happy pieces of music and those in which they were primed by sad music. The former condition, but not the latter, was associated with a significant effect in frontal and central electrodes during the 50-150 millisecond time window.

This study demonstrates that activity in one sensory system can modulate activity in another. ... It also supports the earlier finding that happy and sad emotions evoked by music produce different physiological responses in the brain, and suggests that “binding” of auditory and visual emotional cues occurs at an early stage of neural processing.

ENGLISH.OPT4: Happy music made happy faces seem even happier while sad music exaggerated the melancholy of a frown.

Conversely, sad faces primed by a piece of sad music were rated as sadder than those primed with a happy piece of music. Finally, neutral faces were rated higher when primed by a happy piece of music and lower when primed by a sad piece.

The size of the priming effect for neutral faces was found to be almost twice that of the effect for happy and sad faces. Neutral faces contain less information than those expressing one emotion or the other, and hence are ambiguous. The brain integrates information from different senses to construct representations of the external and internal worlds; thus, in the absence of relevant visual information, it may therefore become more reliant on information from other senses when generating these representations.

The second experiment involved 15 different participants. Logeswaran and Bhattacharya used electroencephalogram (EEG) to record event-related potentials – the electrical activity in the brain associated with perception of the auditory and visual stimuli presented. A number of earlier EEG studies have shown that our emotional responses to music are associated with distinct patterns of brain activation – a happy piece of music causes an increase in activity recorded from electrodes lying over the left frontal and temporal lobes, while pieces of music which evoke negative emotions are associated with increased activity in the right frontal and temporal lobe. A similar lateralized effect has also been observed for emotionally significant visual stimuli.

The researchers compared pairs of conditions in which photographs of the same facial emotion were primed differently. In both conditions, a signal associated with the later stages of face processing, called the face-specific N170 component, was measured from electrodes overlying the occipital and parietal lobes, initially from frontal and central electrodes, followed by more activity in the electrodes located toward the back of the skull. However, a difference was observed between those in conditions in which neutral faces were primed by happy pieces of music and those in which they were primed by sad music. The former condition, but not the latter, was associated with a significant effect in frontal and central electrodes during the 50-150 millisecond time window.

This study demonstrates that activity in one sensory system can modulate activity in another. ... It also supports the earlier finding that happy and sad emotions evoked by music produce different physiological responses in the brain, and suggests that “binding” of auditory and visual emotional cues occurs at an early stage of neural processing.

ENGLISH.EASSY_DETAILS:
DIRECTIONS for questions 19 to 24: The passage given below is followed by a set of six questions. Choose the best answer to each question.

Limbo of the Lost. Twilight Zone. Hoodoo Sea. Devil"s Triangle. The Bermuda Triangle did not receive its famous nickname until 1964. The Bermuda Triangle is a mythical section of the Atlantic Ocean roughly bounded by Miami, Bermuda, and Puerto Rico. Its vicinity is one of the most heavily traveled shipping lanes in the world, with ships frequently crossing through it for ports in the Americas and the Caribbean islands.

No one keeps statistics, but many ships/ planes have vanished in the Bermuda triangle without a trace. William Shakespeare’s play “The Tempest,” based on a real-life Bermuda shipwreck, may have enhanced the area’s aura of mystery. Christopher Columbus wrote about bizarre compass bearings in the area ... and reported that a great flame of fire crashed into the sea one night.

The legend of the Bermuda Triangle will be forever tied to Flight 19 – a training flight of five TBM Avenger torpedo bombers carrying 14 men that disappeared on December 5, 1945 in the Atlantic. The squadron"s flight plan, scheduled to take them due east from Fort Lauderdale, included a few bombing practice runs over Hen and Chickens Shoals. The crewmen of the five Avengers were inexperienced trainees, with the exception of their patrol leader, Lt. Charles Taylor. With the four rookie pilots dependent on his guidance, Taylor found that his compass malfunctioned soon into the flight.

Taylor chose to continue the run on dead reckoning, navigating by sighting landmarks below. But visibility became poor due to a brewing storm, and he quickly became disoriented. The planes flew in one direction then another as balmy daylight turned to stormy seas in the darkness. Taylor ended up thinking they were over the Gulf of Mexico, and ordered the patrol east in search of land. But in reality, they had been heading up the Atlantic coastline, and Taylor was mistakenly leading his hapless trainees much further out to sea. Radio recordings indicate that some of them suggested to Taylor that Florida was actually to the west. ... Taylor was heard formulating a plan as soon as the first plane’s fuel level dipped below 10 gallons. But all five planes were to be buried in the graveyard of the Atlantic. A navy report intimated that the Avengers had disappeared “as if they had flown to Mars”. No known wreckage from Flight 19 has ever been recovered.

The Avenger was known as an extremely rugged plane. Pilots sometimes called them "Iron Birds" or Grumman ironworks. They were also very heavy, weighing more than 10,000 pounds empty. When ditched, the Avenger would go down hard and fast.

A rescue aircraft, a PBM Mariner with a 13-man crew, was deployed to look for Flight 19 survivors but it also disappeared. A tanker off the coast of Florida reported seeing an explosion and observing a widespread oil slick. According to contemporaneous sources, the Mariner had a history of explosions due to vapour leaks when heavily loaded with fuel and had been nicknamed the "flying gas tank" (The slightest spark could cause an explosion!).

The controversial disappearance of Flight 19 and various other disappearances have been attributed to the machinations of enormous sea monsters, giant squids, extra-terrestrials, alien abductions, Atlantis, time warps, reverse gravity fields and ocean flatulence (where trapped methane was spewed by the ocean). ...

There are some obstacles in taking the Bermuda Triangle legend seriously. Most of the associated mishaps can be explained by rational means and many of them did not occur within the Bermuda Triangle. Sea disasters as distant as Portugal, Ireland and the Pacific and Indian Oceans have been blamed on the Bermuda Triangle. We might then just as well rename it as “The Worldwide Curse of All Seas”. Some have turned this fact on its head by proposing this as evidence that the Devil’s Triangle is expanding in scope. Others may respond that it is evidence that accidents will happen – no matter where exactly on the land, on the sea or in the air they take place.

One of the problems suffered by a species on the brink of extinction is low genetic diversity. Initially this is caused by lack of numbers, but then it is exacerbated by the inbreeding which inevitably results. Inbreeding brings with it infertility and susceptibility to disease. Hence concern for the kakapo, a nocturnal parrot that lives in New Zealand. Like many other island-dwelling birds, it has become flightless. It is also, at up to 4kg, the world’s heaviest parrot.

____________________________________________________
ENGLISH.OPT1: So conservationists have come up with a plan to put the parrot on a more secure footing, by reducing, as far as possible, the risks inbreeding brings.
ENGLISH.OPT2: The kakapo’s downfall began with New Zealand’s first wave of human colonization, some 700 years ago, by Polynesians.
ENGLISH.OPT3: Both of these things make it an attractive target for predatory mammals, which thankfully were absent for most of the 80m years during which it and its ancestors have inhabited the archipelago.
ENGLISH.OPT4: That is still a pretty dangerous state of affairs, though.

“Amateurs talk strategy, but professionals talk logistics.” That military maxim’s latest consequence is the adoption by the world’s armed forces of three-dimensional (3D) printing on the front line. It will be a while before weapons robust enough for military use can be printed on demand. But if it is a question of replacing a small but crucial component that has broken – the modern equivalent of reshoeing a horse – then making what is needed to order in this way has huge potential. Moving replacement parts through a long supply chain to a far-flung ship or base can take weeks. And, if a war is on, such convoys make tempting targets. Yet it is unrealistic to keep a full range of spares near the front line. __________________________________________
ENGLISH.OPT1: Having access to a printer can even encourage innovation.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Far better to produce what is needed, when it is needed.
ENGLISH.OPT3: In time, however, metal parts may also be printed at sea.
